importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The article reports on events occurring during the third week of a government shutdown, highlighting the growing impact on federal workers and public services.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The shutdown has entered its third week, demonstrating prolonged disruption to federal operations and increasing public concern over worker welfare and government functionality.

keyTakeAways: Over 1.4 million federal employees have been furloughed or are working without pay due to the government shutdown.

Federal workers, including contractors and employees from agencies like the Department of Commerce and Social Security Administration, are facing financial hardship as rent and basic living expenses go unpaid.
A food bank and religious outreach group hosted a food distribution event for federal workers, serving over 370 households — more than double the expected number — underscoring the scale of need.

Some federal workers, such as Rolanda Williams and Summer Kerksick, express shock at the loss of job security and financial stability, indicating a breakdown in public perception of federal employment as a stable source of income.
Lawmakers remain divided: GOP Sen. Ron Johnson proposes paying only those who continue working, while Democrats advocate for full payment of all federal workers.
The event required federal employees to show work IDs, illustrating both the scale of the shutdown and the need for accountability and verification in public aid distribution.

namedEntities.name: Summer Kerksick
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Federal contractor and market research analyst with the Rural Export Center, US Department of Commerce
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She is a representative example of a federal worker suffering financial hardship during the shutdown, illustrating how even non-regularly employed staff are affected.

namedEntities.name: Ron Johnson
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He introduced a legislative proposal to pay only federal workers who are required to work during the shutdown, reflecting a partisan divide on the scope of worker compensation.

namedEntities.name: Capital Area Food Bank
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Food bank organizing food distribution events
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It serves as a critical humanitarian response to the federal workforce crisis, providing immediate relief to those affected by the shutdown.

namedEntities.name: No Limits Outreach Ministries
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Local religious group organizing food outreach events
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It collaborates with the Capital Area Food Bank to provide food to federal workers, demonstrating community-based efforts to address public needs during government inaction.

namedEntities.name: Pamelia Carter
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Executive director of No Limits Outreach Ministries and former federal employee at the Department of Agriculture
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Her personal experience as a long-time federal worker gives context to the emotional and financial toll of repeated shutdowns on public servants.

namedEntities.name: Rolanda Williams
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Employee at the Social Security Administration
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She exemplifies how federal job security is being eroded during the shutdown, shifting public perception from job stability to vulnerability.

namedEntities.name: Rural Export Center
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Office within the US Department of Commerce
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Houses a federal contractor, Summer Kerksick, showing that even specialized or contractor-based roles are impacted by the shutdown.

namedEntities.name: Department of Commerce
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The department includes federal contractors and employees who are now furloughed, illustrating the broad reach of the shutdown across government branches.

namedEntities.name: Department of Agriculture
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Home to Pamelia Carter, a long-time employee who has experienced shutdowns, providing a historical perspective on federal employee hardship.

namedEntities.name: Social Security Administration
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Houses Rolanda Williams, highlighting the impact of the shutdown on frontline public service employees.

summaryOfNewsArticle: During the third week of a government shutdown, over 1.4 million federal workers, including contractors and employees from agencies like the Department of Commerce and Social Security Administration, are furloughed or working without pay. In response, a joint food distribution event organized by the Capital Area Food Bank and No Limits Outreach Ministries in Landover, Maryland, served more than 370 households — far exceeding expectations — as federal workers like Summer Kerksick and Rolanda Williams expressed financial distress and a loss of job security. The event required work IDs to verify eligibility, highlighting both the scale of need and the operational realities of aid distribution. Lawmakers remain divided, with GOP Senator Ron Johnson proposing payment only for workers who continue working, while Democrats push for universal compensation. This event underscores the human cost of prolonged government shutdowns, challenging public assumptions about federal employment as a stable source of livelihood.
title: Federal workers form line down the block for food pantry as shutdown hits third-week mark
